docs.abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on whether to step in when you see a parent publicly berating a child and more.
docs.snippet: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on whether to step in when you see a parent publicly berating a child and more.
docs.lead_paragraph: As I was rounding the corner in my neighborhood, I saw a teenage girl and her father in an argument. She appeared to be about 15 and was wearing a hoodie, with dyed hair; she generally looked the part of a rebellious, sullen teen. Walking behind him, the daughter kicked at her father’s heels. He responded by whipping around and throwing his full cup of coffee in her face. She responded with a number of expletives, but seemed unfazed and unhurt.

headline.main: Should I Intervene When I See a Parent Mistreating a Child?
headline.print_headline: Should I Intervene When I See a Parent Mistreating a Child?

docs.abstract: To engage the concept of a “still life” painting, this tender poem pauses and holds.
docs.snippet: To engage the concept of a “still life” painting, this tender poem pauses and holds.
docs.lead_paragraph: To engage the concept of a “still life” painting, this tender poem by Mark Sanders pauses and holds. Memory permeates awareness again and again, illuminating the absent, suggesting not that we keep it alive but that it may keep us alive. Sometimes the plums or ceramic pitchers in a painting feel more vivid than the ones on our tables right in front of us. It may take, as the poet William Stafford used to say, a certain tilt of the head to perceive it. Here in this poem, no one is gone. Selected by Naomi Shihab Nye

byline.original: By Mark Sanders and Naomi Shihab Nye

docs.abstract: In a rush of breath and syllables, someone lives and departs, is gone without being gone.
docs.snippet: In a rush of breath and syllables, someone lives and departs, is gone without being gone.
docs.lead_paragraph: A poem can hold mysteries more easily than any factual timeline. In a rush of breath and syllables, someone lives and departs, is gone without being gone, diminished then departed, but reappearing always, unexpectedly, in indelible ways. In “pray me stay eager,” the collection in which this poem appears, Ellen Doré Watson is a master of the spontaneous moment, the merging and blending of consciousness, the delicious difficulties of relationships and questions rising from an intensified experience. Selected by Naomi Shihab Nye

byline.original: By Ellen Doré Watson and Naomi Shihab Nye

docs.abstract: When I decided to binge watch several dozen spaghetti westerns, I didn’t expect the dubbing to be one of the best parts. It was.
docs.snippet: When I decided to binge watch several dozen spaghetti westerns, I didn’t expect the dubbing to be one of the best parts. It was.
docs.lead_paragraph: Last winter, I decided it would be a good idea to watch several dozen spaghetti westerns over the course of approximately two months. The exercise originated as research for a book but soon settled into a soothing nightly ritual. I hadn’t realized the stress of scrolling through peak-streaming-era viewing options had been a stress at all, not until I deliberately limited myself to a minuscule subsection of the infinite menu. It practically felt like a mindfulness meditation.

headline.main: Letter of Recommendation: Badly Dubbed Movies

docs.abstract: Her style was always her own, from the geometry of the clothing she designed to the elegance of her life.
docs.snippet: Her style was always her own, from the geometry of the clothing she designed to the elegance of her life.
docs.lead_paragraph: Her style was always her own, from the geometry of the clothing she designed to the elegance of her life.

docs.abstract: Before he died, my father never talked about his time in the military. Now I’m trying to put the pieces together using the clues he left behind.
docs.snippet: Before he died, my father never talked about his time in the military. Now I’m trying to put the pieces together using the clues he left behind.
docs.lead_paragraph: I nestled into bed with a paperback copy of “The Things They Carried,” by Tim O’Brien. It had belonged to my dad. He thought the 1990 collection of short stories was the most realistic portrayal of the Vietnam War he had ever read. My father, Jack Reilly, died five years ago, and this book was one of the pieces I had left of him.

headline.main: Uncovering My Father’s Vietnam Service Through the Things He Carried

headline.main: Behind the Cover: The Lives They Lived

docs.abstract: As the United Kingdom confronts the prospect of dissolution, old factions are bracing for the possibility of new violence.
docs.snippet: As the United Kingdom confronts the prospect of dissolution, old factions are bracing for the possibility of new violence.
docs.lead_paragraph: Belfast, like Berlin and Sarajevo, draws many visitors not despite its history of murderous conflict but because of it. Guides there take tourists to “peace walls,” the tall barricades of corrugated metal and concrete erected during the sectarian conflict, known as the Troubles, that began in 1968 and ravaged Northern Ireland for three decades. The walls were built to divide Protestant and Catholic enclaves and to prevent people from killing one another as the spiraling cycle of attacks took hold. Today tourists from around the world visit the walls and take selfies. This type of tourism is more peculiar in Belfast than in some other cities shaped by a legacy of atrocity. You can visit the intact parts of the Berlin Wall, for instance, with the knowledge that the wall no longer serves its original purpose. In Belfast, however, the walls are still there to divide, their continued presence deemed necessary to prevent a resurgence of violence.

headline.main: Will Brexit Bring the Troubles Back to Northern Ireland?

docs.abstract: It’s natural for a rising candidate to get kicked around. But the nature of the backlash says a lot about the past decade of Democratic politics.
docs.snippet: It’s natural for a rising candidate to get kicked around. But the nature of the backlash says a lot about the past decade of Democratic politics.
docs.lead_paragraph: Last month, after polls showed Pete Buttigieg vaulting unexpectedly to the lead in Iowa’s Democratic caucus, he aired an ad introducing his plan for higher-education reform: a proposal to make public-college tuition free for households earning up to $100,000 a year and reduce it on a sliding scale for those making up to $150,000. “Some voices,” he says in the ad, want to make college “free, even for the kids of millionaires” — a swipe at his rivals to the left, Elizabeth Warren and Bernie Sanders, who had each called for free college for all.

headline.main: How the Internet Came to Loathe Pete Buttigieg
